entry.content:
I'm at the hospital right now, in Canada, and I have to say that my treatment here was very pleasant. The calmness and professionalism of the medical professionals in my small, rural town - and that they got out of bed to take care of me - has changed my priors on medical expertise and public healthcare in general.
I have had very little contact with my country's medical system, for many reasons, but I think I'm going to give the medical profession the benefit of the doubt going forward. I know it's not very culture-warry but it was a personal experience I thought was worth sharing.
Now, I did show up at the hospital without my medical services card (so my coverage is right now unknown) but it most likely will be fully covered. Perhaps my anecdote won't change very many minds, but I have to make my mea culpas: even with COVID still going on, I got a doctor, a x-ray tech, and a blood test a little under two hours from admission.
Perhaps it is worth saving, after all...
